Let's first import and read our data set.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cartoon <- read_csv("C:/Users/khush/Downloads/cartoon.csv")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Rows: 91 Columns: 4
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (3): Participant ID, Gender, Cartoon
dbl (1): Rating

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
cartoon
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 91 × 4
   `Participant ID` Gender     Cartoon           Rating
   <chr>            <chr>      <chr>              <dbl>
```

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
glimpse(cartoon)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Rows: 91
Columns: 4
$ `Participant ID` <chr> "M1", "M2", "M3", "M4", "M5", "M6", "M7", "M8", "M9",…
$ Gender           <chr> "Male\xa0", "Male\xa0", "Male\xa0", "Male\xa0", "Male…
$ Cartoon          <chr> "Chota Bheem\xa0", "Chota Bheem\xa0", "Chota Bheem\xa…
$ Rating           <dbl> 8.5, 6.0, 8.0, 7.0, 8.0, 10.0, 5.0, 7.8, 8.5, 5.0, 7.…
```


:::
:::




## Data Munging




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cartoon2 <- cartoon %>% 
  mutate(
    Gender = as_factor(Gender),
    Cartoon = as_factor(Cartoon)
  )
glimpse(cartoon)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Rows: 91
Columns: 4
$ `Participant ID` <chr> "M1", "M2", "M3", "M4", "M5", "M6", "M7", "M8", "M9",…
$ Gender           <chr> "Male\xa0", "Male\xa0", "Male\xa0", "Male\xa0", "Male…
$ Cartoon          <chr> "Chota Bheem\xa0", "Chota Bheem\xa0", "Chota Bheem\xa…
$ Rating           <dbl> 8.5, 6.0, 8.0, 7.0, 8.0, 10.0, 5.0, 7.8, 8.5, 5.0, 7.…
```


:::
:::




#### *NULL Hypothesis for this data set?*\~




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Calculate mean and standard deviation of Rating
summary_stats <- cartoon %>%
  summarize(
    Mean_Rating = mean(Rating, na.rm = TRUE),
    SD_Rating = sd(Rating, na.rm = TRUE)
  )

# Print the summary statistics
print(summary_stats)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 1 × 2
  Mean_Rating SD_Rating
        <dbl>     <dbl>
1        7.06      1.93
```


:::
:::




#### *Histogram*\~




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(cartoon, aes(x = Rating)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1, fill = "blue", color = "black", alpha = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Histogram of Ratings",
       x = "Rating",
       y = "Frequency") +
  theme_minimal()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
unique(cartoon$Gender)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "Male\xa0" "Female"   "Male"    
```


:::
:::




#### *ANOVA*\~




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cartoon_anova <- aov(Rating ~ Cartoon, data = cartoon2)
cartoon_anova
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Call:
   aov(formula = Rating ~ Cartoon, data = cartoon2)

Terms:
                 Cartoon Residuals
Sum of Squares    6.8619  327.9735
Deg. of Freedom        2        88

Residual standard error: 1.930537
Estimated effects may be unbalanced
```


:::
:::




#### *Check for Normality*\~




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(x = cartoon2$Rating)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  cartoon2$Rating
W = 0.93514, p-value = 0.0002078
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cartoon2 %>%
  group_by(Cartoon) %>%
  group_modify(~ .x %>%
    select(Rating) %>%
    as_vector() %>%
    shapiro.test() %>%
    broom::tidy())
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 3 × 4
# Groups:   Cartoon [3]
  Cartoon           statistic p.value method                     
  <fct>                 <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>                      
1 "Chota Bheem\xa0"     0.951  0.185  Shapiro-Wilk normality test
2 "Doraemon"            0.909  0.0139 Shapiro-Wilk normality test
3 "Dragon Tales"        0.916  0.0184 Shapiro-Wilk normality test
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cartoon2 %>%
  as_tibble() %>%
  gf_dhistogram(~Rating, data = .) %>%
  gf_fitdistr()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




The ratings appear to be spread across with several peaks, indicating that the data may not follow a simple normal distribution..

#### *Permutation Test*\~




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
observed_infer <- cartoon2 %>%
  specify(Rating ~ Cartoon) %>%
  hypothesise(null = "independence") %>%
  calculate(stat = "F")
observed_infer
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Response: Rating (numeric)
Explanatory: Cartoon (factor)
Null Hypothesis: independence
# A tibble: 1 × 1
   stat
  <dbl>
1 0.921
```


:::
:::




The F-stat of 0.9 suggests that there is little to no difference in the means of the ratings of cartoons being compared.

After this, we perform the permutation test.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
null_dist_infer <- cartoon2 %>%
  specify(Rating ~ Cartoon) %>%
  hypothesise(null = "independence") %>%
  generate(reps = 4999, type = "permute") %>%
  calculate(stat = "F")
##
null_dist_infer
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Response: Rating (numeric)
Explanatory: Cartoon (factor)
Null Hypothesis: independence
# A tibble: 4,999 × 2
   replicate  stat
       <int> <dbl>
 1         1 0.642
 2         2 0.303
 3         3 1.00 
 4         4 0.507
 5         5 0.373
 6         6 0.499
 7         7 5.18 
 8         8 1.07 
 9         9 0.829
10        10 0.276
# ℹ 4,989 more rows
```


:::
:::




This null distribution allows us to evaluate the stance of the F-stat value. By comparing the observed F-stat to this null distribution, we can assess how unusual or extreme it is.

The distribution across all 4,999 samples show the overall spread of F-values under the null hypothesis.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
##
null_dist_infer %>%
  visualise(method = "simulation") +
  shade_p_value(obs_stat = observed_infer$stat, direction = "right") +
  scale_x_continuous(trans = "log10", expand = c(0, 0)) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0.2, 500), clip = "off") +
  annotation_logticks(outside = FALSE) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning in transformation$transform(x): NaNs produced
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning in scale_x_continuous(trans = "log10", expand = c(0, 0)): log-10
transformation introduced infinite values.
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
